data.label: Quick Start Button
data.description: A set of action buttons to start a specific conversation by suggesting possible topics or actions.

data.label: Sticker Chat Messages
data.description: A message containing or only consisting of a Sticker.

data.label: Input adjustment
data.description: A request for how a chatbot should reply or generate answers e.g. "thinking" mode versus responding fast.

data.label: Web Preview Chat Message
data.description: A preview on web content from other providers or the chatbot homepage itself.

data.label: Accordion
data.description: The Accordion is a well known pattern from graphical user interfaces and is used to hide information to save space. In the analysed chatbots, Accordions are used either to shorten a very long chat message or to provide a short insight into several available search results. Some chatbots also include a similar option to show more Quick Replies for the users.

data.label: Interactive canvas
data.description: kind of like a canvas that both chatbot and user can edit/work on, can be text based (e.g. for writing code together) or possibly graphical or other

data.label: Conversation Recovery
data.description: Avoiding conversation breakdowns by providing possible actions or commands.

data.label: Call- on Menu
data.description: A dynamic representation of consistent information which was requested by the user. (1., 4., 6.

data.label: Request/Message Completion
data.description: completion of chatmessage, inspired by Google and maybe motivated by chatbots taking over web search

data.label: Persistent Menu
data.description: A constant menu in the chat window for important information or settings

data.label: Additional input
data.description:
A possibility to upload of extra information inf form of documents or media. It can also be a request for specific actions of chatbot, like generate image, story etc.
possible other actions going beyond messaging.

data.label: System Information
data.description: This pattern presents itself by offering information on the chatbot system outside of the conversation with the entity chatbot itself. It is provided as banners or like “news tickers” above or underneath the respective footer or header of the chatbot, but can also be presented as a small pop-up or even span the complete area of the chatbot interface before access is given. As such, it mostly provides information on data protection, although the pattern can also inform on technical limitations of the chatbot. For this pattern we do not include any information provided via the persistent menu.

data.label: Voice Chat Messages
data.description: A voice-based message that can be either transferred invoice or voice-to-text mode or as a voice message

data.label: Help System
data.description: Offering assistance for users, either on request or proactively by the chatbot.

data.label: Message Reactions
data.description: Emojis or symbolsbeside or under a chat message to provide feedback or allow for other actions (e.g. re-generate, change language) on the answer of the chatbot.

data.label: Image Chat Messages
data.description: A message containing or only consisting of an image.

data.label: dialogue reload
data.description: Of the analysed chatbots, 5 offer the option to reload the dialogue and start the conversation again. As such, it can help to solve situations in which the chatbot does not understand the user which might lead to frustrations. This can be seen as a specific sub-pattern of Conversation Recovery. The difference to that pattern is that Conversation Recovery is provided by the chatbot at best without a specific prompt from the user. The Dialogue Reload on the other hand is an action consciously taken by the user if they recognize that the chatbot either does not function as intended or cannot provide a satisfactory answer.

data.label: Processing Indicators
data.description: A visual representation of the waiting time (typing, thinking, generating, doing, ...) for the reply of the chatbot. (1.)

data.label: Functionality Introduction
data.description: Introducing the main functionalities or providing a tutorial in the first chat messages.

data.label: Quick Replies
data.description: A set of actions or functionalities under a chat message in the form of buttons.

data.label: Information Stamps
data.description: Some chatbots include information on the time, user and context of the conversation. Most often this is done by including the time at which a chat message was sent either above or beneath that message (8 times). This is sometimes accompanied by the date or name of the sender, so either the chatbot name, ‘guest’ or a given name for the user (3 times). Some chatbots only provided the current date on top of the chat (4 times), while one also provides information on the current topic of the conversation.

data.label: Text Chat Messages
data.description: Displaying outputs from chatbot and user, most often as speech bubbles.
